<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL">
	Capital expenditures of $1.2&nbsp;billion for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2016 exclude $343&nbsp;million of accrued capital
	expenditures remaining unpaid at December&nbsp;31, 2016 and include payment for $322&nbsp;million of capital expenditures that were accrued and unpaid at December&nbsp;31, 2015.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL">
	In connection with our restructuring program, we recorded
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-cash
</FONT>
	asset write-downs (including accelerated depreciation and
	asset impairments) of $301&nbsp;million in 2016, $264&nbsp;million in 2015 and $173&nbsp;million in 2014 (see Note 6,
<I>
	Restructuring Programs
</I>
	). These charges were recorded in the consolidated statements of earnings within asset impairment and
	exit costs and in the following segment results as follows:
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:12PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>

<P STYLE=" MARGIN-TOP:0PT ; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; BORDER-TOP:3.00PX DOUBLE #000000">
	&nbsp;
</P>
</TD>

	&nbsp;
</TD>

</TABLE>

</EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" ALIGN="CENTER">
	80
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage83"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D288385D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL">
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Non-amortizable
</FONT>
	intangible assets consist principally of brand names purchased
	through our acquisitions of Nabisco Holdings Corp., the Spanish and Portuguese operations of United Biscuits, the global
<I>
	LU
</I>
	biscuit business of Groupe Danone S.A. and Cadbury Limited. Amortizable intangible assets consist primarily of
	trademarks, customer-related intangibles, process technology, licenses and
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-compete
</FONT>
	agreements. At December&nbsp;31, 2016, the weighted-average life of our amortizable intangible assets was 13.5 years.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL">
	Amortization expense for intangible assets was $176&nbsp;million in 2016, $181&nbsp;million in 2015 and $206&nbsp;million in 2014. We currently estimate annual
	amortization expense for each of the next five years to be approximately $171&nbsp;million, estimated using December&nbsp;31, 2016 exchange rates.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL">
	Changes in
	goodwill and intangible assets consisted of:
</P>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL">
	Changes to goodwill and intangibles were:
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="5%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	&#149;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	Coffee business transactions and divestitures &#150; On December&nbsp;1, 2016, we divested $4&nbsp;million of goodwill related to the sale of a confectionery business in Costa Rica. On May&nbsp;2, 2016, we sold
	$8&nbsp;million of
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-amortizable
</FONT>
	intangible assets in Finland. On July&nbsp;2, 2015, we deconsolidated $1,664&nbsp;million of goodwill and less than $1&nbsp;million of intangible assets in connection with
	the coffee business transactions. On April&nbsp;23, 2015, we completed the divestiture of our 50% equity interest in AGF, which resulted in divesting $65&nbsp;million of goodwill. See Note 2,
<I>
	Divestitures and Acquisitions
</I>
	, for additional
	information on these transactions.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="5%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	&#149;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	Acquisitions &#150; On November&nbsp;2, 2016, we purchased from Burton&#146;s Biscuit Company certain intangibles, which include a license to manufacture, market and sell Cadbury-branded biscuits in additional key
	markets. As a result of the acquisition, we recorded a preliminary purchase price allocation of $156&nbsp;million to goodwill and $72&nbsp;million to amortizable intangible assets. In connection with the completion of the Vietnam biscuit operation
	in 2016, we finalized the purchase price allocation of the consideration paid to the net assets acquired and recorded $25&nbsp;million of amortizable intangible assets and $61&nbsp;million of
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-amortizable
</FONT>
	intangible assets related to acquired trademarks and customer-related intangible assets. A preliminary goodwill balance was recorded in the third quarter of 2015 and subsequently adjusted by $76&nbsp;million to $385&nbsp;million during the first
	nine months of 2016 to reflect finalized intangible asset and other asset fair valuations. On February&nbsp;16, 2015, we also acquired Enjoy Life Foods and recorded $20&nbsp;million of goodwill and $58&nbsp;million in identifiable intangible assets.
	See Note 2,
<I>
	Divestitures and Acquisitions &#150; Other Divestitures and Acquisitions
</I>
	, for additional information.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="5%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	&#149;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	Asset impairments &#150; We recorded $137&nbsp;million of intangible asset impairments in 2016, $83&nbsp;million in 2015 and $57&nbsp;million in 2014. Charges related to our annual testing of
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-amortizable
</FONT>
	intangible assets are described further below. Additionally, during 2016, $20&nbsp;million of impairments recorded in our Europe segment related to the planned sale of a confectionery business in
	France (see Note 2,
<I>
	Divestitures and Acquisitions &#150; Other Divestitures and Acquisitions
</I>
	, for additional information). In 2016, we also recorded $19&nbsp;million of charges in our Europe, North America and AMEA segments resulting from the
	discontinuation of four biscuit products and one candy product. Additionally, in 2015, in connection with the deconsolidation of our Venezuelan operations on December&nbsp;31, 2015, we recorded $12&nbsp;million of impairment charges within the loss
	on deconsolidation of Venezuela related to a biscuit trademark.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" ALIGN="CENTER">
	81
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage84"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D288385D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL">
	In 2016, 2015 and 2014, there were no impairments of goodwill. In connection with our 2016 annual impairment testing, each
	of our reporting units had sufficient fair value in excess of carrying value. While all reporting units passed our annual impairment testing, if planned business performance expectations are not met or specific valuation factors outside of our
	control, such as discount rates, change significantly, then the estimated fair values of a reporting unit or reporting units might decline and lead to a goodwill impairment in the future.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL">
	During our 2016 annual testing of
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-amortizable
</FONT>
	intangible assets, we recorded $98&nbsp;million of impairment charges related
	to five trademarks.&nbsp;The impairments arose due to lower than expected product growth in part driven by decisions to redirect support from these trademarks to other regional and global brands, as well as slowdowns in local economies. We recorded
	charges related to biscuits, candy and gum trademarks of $41&nbsp;million in AMEA, $32&nbsp;million in North America, $22&nbsp;million in Europe, and $3&nbsp;million in Latin America. The impairment charges were calculated as the excess of the
	carrying value over the estimated fair value of the intangible assets on a global basis and were recorded within asset impairment and exit costs. We primarily use a relief of royalty valuation method, which&nbsp;utilizes estimates of future sales,
	growth rates, royalty rates and discount rates in determining a brand&#146;s global fair value.&nbsp;During our 2016 intangible asset impairment review, we noted nine brands, including the five impaired trademarks, with $630&nbsp;million of
	aggregate book value as of December&nbsp;31, 2016 that each had a fair value in excess of book value of 10% or less. While the other four intangible assets passed our annual impairment testing and we believe our current plans for each of these
	brands will allow them to continue to not be impaired, if the product line expectations are not met or specific valuation factors outside of our control, such as discount rates, change significantly, then a brand or brands could become impaired in
	the future. In 2015, we recorded a $44&nbsp;million charge related to candy and biscuit trademarks in our AMEA segment, $22&nbsp;million in Europe and $5&nbsp;million in Latin America. In 2014, we recorded a $48&nbsp;million charge related to a
	biscuit trademark in our AMEA segment and a $9&nbsp;million charge related to a candy trademark in our Europe segment.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL">
<B>
	Note 6. Restructuring Programs
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL">
	On May&nbsp;6, 2014, our Board of Directors approved a $3.5&nbsp;billion restructuring program, comprised of approximately $2.5&nbsp;billion in cash costs and
	$1&nbsp;billion in
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-cash
</FONT>
	costs (the &#147;2014-2018 Restructuring Program&#148;) and up to $2.2&nbsp;billion of capital expenditures. On August&nbsp;31, 2016, our Board of Directors approved a reallocation
	within the $5.7&nbsp;billion total cost of the programs of $600&nbsp;million of previously approved capital expenditures to be spent on restructuring program cash costs. There was no change to the total $5.7&nbsp;billion cost of the programs and no
	change to the total $4.7&nbsp;billion of cash outlays. The $5.7&nbsp;billion total cost of the programs is now comprised of approximately $4.1&nbsp;billion of restructuring program costs ($3.1&nbsp;billion cash costs and $1 billion non-cash costs)
	and up to $1.6&nbsp;billion of capital expenditures. The primary objective of the 2014-2018 Restructuring Program is to reduce our operating cost structure in both our supply chain and overhead costs. The program is intended primarily to cover
	severance as well as asset disposals and other manufacturing-related
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	one-time
</FONT>
	costs. Since inception, we have incurred total restructuring and related implementation charges of $2.5&nbsp;billion related to the
	2014-2018 Restructuring Program. We have incurred the majority of the program&#146;s charges through 2016 and we expect to complete the program by
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	year-end
</FONT>
	2018.
</P>
<EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<A NAME="FIS_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE_47"></A>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" ALIGN="CENTER">
	82
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage85"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D288385D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL">
	We spent $315&nbsp;million in 2016 and $243&nbsp;million in 2015 in cash severance and related costs. We also recognized
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-cash
</FONT>
	pension settlement losses (See Note 9,
<I>
	Benefit Plans
</I>
	),
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-cash
</FONT>
	asset write-downs (including accelerated depreciation and asset impairments) and other
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-cash
</FONT>
	adjustments totaling $321&nbsp;million in 2016 and $273&nbsp;million in 2015. At December&nbsp;31, 2016, $379&nbsp;million of our net restructuring liability was recorded within other current liabilities
	and $85&nbsp;million was recorded within other long-term liabilities.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL">
<I>
	Implementation Costs:
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL">
	Implementation costs are directly attributable to restructuring activities; however, they do not qualify for special accounting treatment as exit or disposal activities.
	We believe the disclosure of implementation costs provides readers of our financial statements with more information on the total costs of our 2014-2018 Restructuring Program. Implementation costs primarily relate to reorganizing our operations and
	facilities in connection with our supply chain reinvention program and other identified productivity and cost saving initiatives. The costs include incremental expenses related to the closure of facilities, costs to terminate certain contracts and
	the simplification of our information systems. Within our continuing results of operations, we recorded implementation costs of $372&nbsp;million in 2016, $291&nbsp;million in 2015 and $107&nbsp;million in 2014. We recorded these costs within cost
	of sales and general corporate expense within selling, general and administrative expenses.
</P>
<EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<A NAME="FIS_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE_48"></A>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL">
<I>
	Restructuring and Implementation Costs in Operating Income:
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL">
	During 2016, 2015 and 2014, we recorded restructuring and implementation costs related to the 2014-2018 Restructuring Program within operating income by segment (as
	revised to reflect our new segment structure) as follows:
</P>

<A NAME="eolPage86"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D288385D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL">
<B>
	2012-2014 Restructuring Program
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL">
	On October&nbsp;1, 2012, we completed the
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Spin-Off
</FONT>
	of our North American grocery business, Kraft Foods Group, to our
	shareholders. Prior to this transaction, in 2012, our Board of Directors approved $1.5&nbsp;billion of restructuring and related implementation costs (the &#147;2012-2014 Restructuring Program&#148;) reflecting primarily severance, asset disposals
	and other manufacturing-related
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	one-time
</FONT>
	costs. The primary objective of the 2012-2014 Restructuring Program was to ensure that Mondel&#275;z International and Kraft Foods Group were each set up to operate
	efficiently and execute on our respective business strategies upon separation and in the future.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL">
	Of the $1.5&nbsp;billion of 2012-2014 Restructuring Program costs,
	we retained approximately $925&nbsp;million and Kraft Foods Group retained the balance of the program. Through the end of 2014, we incurred total restructuring and related implementation charges of $899&nbsp;million and completed incurring planned
	charges on the 2012-2014 Restructuring Program.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL">
<I>
	Restructuring Costs:
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL">
	We
	recorded reversals to the restructuring charges of $4&nbsp;million in 2015 related to accruals no longer required. We recorded restructuring charges of $360&nbsp;million in 2014 within asset impairment and exit costs. During 2014, we recorded
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	out-of-period
</FONT>
</FONT>
	accruals for $73&nbsp;million of severance ($52&nbsp;million related to 2014 and $21&nbsp;million related to 2013) in connection with a change in the timing of
	accruals for ongoing negotiations with workers&#146; councils and labor unions.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL">
	The 2012-2014 Restructuring Program liability activity for the years ended
	December&nbsp;31, 2016 and 2015 was:
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:12PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL">
	We spent $21&nbsp;million in 2016 and $66&nbsp;million in 2015 in cash severance and related costs. We also recognized
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-cash
</FONT>
	pension plan settlement losses (See Note 9,
<I>
	Benefit Plans
</I>
	) and
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-cash
</FONT>
	adjustments totaling $6&nbsp;million in 2016 and $4&nbsp;million in 2015. At
	December&nbsp;31, 2016, $18&nbsp;million of our net restructuring liability was recorded within other current liabilities and less than $1&nbsp;million was recorded within other long-term liabilities.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL">
<I>
	Implementation Costs:
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL">
	Implementation costs related to our 2012-2014
	Restructuring Program primarily relate to activities in connection with the Kraft Foods Group
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Spin-Off
</FONT>
	such as reorganizing our operations and facilities, the discontinuance of certain product lines and
	incremental expenses related to the closure of facilities, replicating our information systems infrastructure and reorganizing our sales function. Within our continuing results of operations, we recorded implementation costs of $99&nbsp;million in
	2014. We recorded these costs within cost of sales and selling, general and administrative expenses.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" ALIGN="CENTER">
	84
</P>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL">
	As of December&nbsp;31, 2016, the commercial paper issued and outstanding had between 3 and 88 days remaining to maturity. Bank
	loans include borrowings on primarily uncommitted credit lines maintained by some of our international subsidiaries to meet short-term working capital needs.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL">
<I>
	Borrowing Arrangements:
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL">
	We maintain a $4.5&nbsp;billion multi-year senior
	unsecured revolving credit facility for general corporate purposes, including working capital needs, and to support our commercial paper program. On October&nbsp;14, 2016, the revolving credit agreement, which was scheduled to expire on
	October&nbsp;11, 2018, was extended through October&nbsp;11, 2021. The revolving credit agreement includes a covenant that we maintain a minimum shareholders&#146; equity of at least $24.6&nbsp;billion, excluding accumulated other comprehensive
	earnings / (losses) and the cumulative effects of any changes in accounting principles. At December&nbsp;31, 2016, we complied with this covenant as our shareholders&#146; equity, as defined by the covenant, was $36.3&nbsp;billion. The revolving
	credit facility agreement also contains customary representations, covenants and events of default. There are no credit rating triggers, provisions or other financial covenants that could require us to post collateral as security. As of
	December&nbsp;31, 2016, no amounts were drawn on the facility.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL">
	Some of our international subsidiaries maintain primarily uncommitted credit lines to meet
	short-term working capital needs. Collectively, these credit lines amounted to $1.8&nbsp;billion at December&nbsp;31, 2016 and $1.9&nbsp;billion at December&nbsp;31, 2015. Borrowings on these lines amounted to $160&nbsp;million at December&nbsp;31,
	2016 and $236&nbsp;million at December 31, 2015.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" ALIGN="CENTER">
	85
</P>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL">
	Deferred debt issuance costs of $40&nbsp;million as of December&nbsp;31, 2016 and $46&nbsp;million as of December&nbsp;31, 2015 are
	netted against the related debt in the table above. These amounts were reclassified from long-term other assets to offset the related debt in the fourth quarter of 2015, except for deferred financing costs related to our revolving credit facility
	which remain in long-term other assets and were immaterial for all periods presented.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL">

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL">
	On December&nbsp;16, 2016, we redeemed $850&nbsp;million of 2.250% fixed rate notes, maturing on February&nbsp;1, 2019, that were
	issued on January&nbsp;16, 2014. The notes were redeemed at a redemption cost equal to $866&nbsp;million, plus accrued and unpaid interest of $7&nbsp;million. In connection with this redemption, during the three months ended December&nbsp;31, 2016,
	we recorded a $19&nbsp;million loss on debt extinguishment within interest and other expense, net.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL">
	On October&nbsp;31, 2016, we completed a cash tender offer and
	retired $3.18&nbsp;billion of U.S. dollar, euro and British pound sterling-denominated notes. We financed the repurchase of the notes, including the payment of accrued interest and other costs incurred, from net proceeds received on October&nbsp;28,
	2016 from the $3.75&nbsp;billion note issuance and the term loans described below. In connection with retiring this debt, during the three months ended December&nbsp;31, 2016, we recorded a $409&nbsp;million loss on debt extinguishment within
	interest expense related to the amount we paid to retire the debt in excess of its carrying value and from recognizing unamortized premiums and deferred financing costs in earnings at the time of the debt extinguishment. Cash costs related to
	tendering the debt are included in long-term debt repayments in the consolidated statement of cash flows for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2016. We also recognized $1&nbsp;million in interest income related to the partial settlement of fair value
	hedges due to the tender.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL">
	On October&nbsp;19, 2016, Mondelez International Holdings Netherlands B.V. (&#147;MIHN&#148;), a wholly owned subsidiary of Mondel&#275;z
	International, Inc., launched an offering of $3.75&nbsp;billion of notes, guaranteed by Mondel&#275;z International, Inc. The $1.75&nbsp;billion of 1.625% notes and the $500&nbsp;million of floating rate notes will mature on October&nbsp;28, 2019
	and the $1.5&nbsp;billion of 2.0% notes will mature on October&nbsp;28, 2021. On October&nbsp;28, 2016, we received proceeds, net of discounts and associated financing costs, of $3.73&nbsp;billion. Proceeds from the notes issuance were used for
	general corporate purposes, including to grant loans or make distributions to Mondel&#275;z International, Inc. or its subsidiaries to fund the October 2016 cash tender offer and near-term debt maturities. We recorded approximately $20&nbsp;million
	of deferred financing costs and discounts, which will be amortized into interest expense over the life of the notes. We entered into cross-currency swaps, serving as cash flow hedges, so that the U.S. dollar-denominated debt payments will
	effectively be paid in euros over the life of the debt.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" ALIGN="CENTER">
	86
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage89"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D288385D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL">
	On October&nbsp;14, 2016, MIHN executed a $1.5&nbsp;billion bank term loan facility. The loan facility consists of two
	$750&nbsp;million loans, one with a three-year maturity and the other with a five-year maturity. The term loans can be drawn at any time for 60 days after signing. On October&nbsp;25, 2016, we gave notice of our intent to fully draw on the loan with
	a five-year maturity, and funding occurred on October&nbsp;28, 2016. Proceeds from the $750&nbsp;million term loan may be used for general corporate purposes, including funding of the tender offer or other debt. On October&nbsp;25, 2016, we also
	gave notice of our intent to terminate the $750&nbsp;million loan with the three-year maturity.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL">
	On February&nbsp;9, 2016, $1,750&nbsp;million of our 4.125% U.S.
	dollar notes matured. The notes and accrued interest to date were paid with net proceeds from the
<I>
	fr
</I>
	.400&nbsp;million Swiss franc-denominated notes issued on January&nbsp;26, 2016 and the
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	&#128;
</FONT>
	700&nbsp;million euro-denominated notes issued on January&nbsp;21, 2016, as well as cash on hand and the issuance of commercial paper. As we refinanced $1,150&nbsp;million of the matured notes
	with net proceeds from the long-term debt issued in January 2016, we reflected this amount within long-term debt as of December&nbsp;31, 2015.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL">
	On January&nbsp;26,
	2016, we issued
<I>
	fr
</I>
	.400&nbsp;million of Swiss franc-denominated notes, or $399&nbsp;million in U.S. dollars locked in with a forward currency contract on January&nbsp;12, 2016, consisting of:
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="5%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	&#149;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<I>
	fr
</I>
	.250&nbsp;million (or $249 million) of 0.080% fixed rate notes that mature on January&nbsp;26, 2018
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">

</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL">
	We received
	proceeds, net of premiums and deferred financing costs, of $398&nbsp;million that were used to partially fund the February 2016 note maturity and for other general corporate purposes. We recorded approximately $1&nbsp;million of premiums and
	deferred financing costs, which will be amortized into interest expense over the life of the notes.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL">
	On January&nbsp;21, 2016, we issued
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	&#128;
</FONT>
	700&nbsp;million of euro-denominated 1.625% notes, or $760&nbsp;million in U.S. dollars locked in with a forward currency contract on January&nbsp;13, 2016. The euro-denominated notes will mature on
	January&nbsp;20, 2023. We received proceeds, net of discounts and deferred financing costs, of $752&nbsp;million that were used to partially fund the February 2016 note maturity and for other general corporate purposes. We recorded approximately
	$8&nbsp;million of discounts and deferred financing costs, which will be amortized into interest expense over the life of the notes.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL">
	On November&nbsp;30, 2015, we
	completed a cash tender offer and retired &pound;247&nbsp;million of British pound sterling-denominated 7.250% notes, or approximately $372&nbsp;million in U.S. dollars as of November&nbsp;30, 2015, due in July 2018. We financed the repurchase of
	these notes, including the payment of accrued interest and other costs incurred, from net proceeds received from the &pound;400&nbsp;million British pound sterling-denominated notes issuance on November&nbsp;25, 2015 described below. In connection
	with retiring this debt, during the three months ended December&nbsp;31, 2015, we recorded a $40&nbsp;million loss on extinguishment of debt within interest expense related to the amount we paid to retire the debt in excess of its carrying value and
	from recognizing unamortized premiums and deferred financing costs in earnings at the time of the debt extinguishment. Cash costs related to tendering the debt are included in long-term debt repayments in the consolidated statement of cash flows for
	the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL">
	On November&nbsp;25, 2015, we issued &pound;400&nbsp;million of British pound sterling-denominated 4.500% notes, or
	$609&nbsp;million in U.S. dollars locked in with a forward currency contract on November&nbsp;19, 2015, that mature on December&nbsp;3, 2035. We received proceeds net of discounts and deferred financing costs of $604&nbsp;million that were used to
	fund the November 2015 cash tender offer and for other general corporate purposes. We recorded approximately $5&nbsp;million of discounts and deferred financing costs, which will be amortized into interest expense over the life of the notes.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL">
	On October&nbsp;6, 2015 we issued
<I>
	fr
</I>
	.400&nbsp;million of Swiss franc-denominated notes, or $410&nbsp;million in U.S. dollars locked in with a forward currency
	contract on September&nbsp;21, 2015, consisting of:

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL">
	We financed the repurchase of these notes, including the
	payment of accrued interest and other costs incurred, from net proceeds received from the $2.8&nbsp;billion notes issuance on March&nbsp;6, 2015 described below and the issuance of commercial paper. In connection with retiring this debt, during the
	first three months of 2015, we recorded a $708&nbsp;million loss on extinguishment of debt within interest expense related to the amount we paid to retire the debt in excess of its carrying value and from recognizing unamortized discounts and
	deferred financing costs in earnings at the time of the debt extinguishment. Cash costs related to tendering the debt are included in long-term debt repayments in the consolidated statement of cash flows for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015. We
	also recognized $5&nbsp;million of charges within interest expense from hedging instruments related to the retired debt. Upon extinguishing the debt, the deferred cash flow hedge amounts were recorded in earnings.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL">

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL">
	Our weighted-average interest rate on our total debt was 2.2% as of December&nbsp;31, 2016, 3.7% as of December&nbsp;31, 2015
	and 4.3% as of December&nbsp;31, 2014.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL">
<I>
	Fair Value of Our Debt:
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL">
	The fair
	value of our short-term borrowings at December&nbsp;31, 2016 and December&nbsp;31, 2015 reflects current market interest rates and approximates the amounts we have recorded on our consolidated balance sheet. The fair value of our long-term debt was
	determined using quoted prices in active markets (Level 1 valuation data) for the publicly traded debt obligations. At December&nbsp;31, 2016, the aggregate fair value of our total debt was $17,882&nbsp;million and its carrying value was
	$17,199&nbsp;million. At December&nbsp;31, 2015, the aggregate fair value of our total debt was $15,908&nbsp;million and its carrying value was $15,398&nbsp;million.
</P>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL">
	See Note 2,
<I>
	Divestitures and Acquisitions,
</I>
	and Note 8,
<I>
	Financial Instruments,
</I>
	for information on the currency
	exchange forward contracts associated with the JDE coffee business transactions. Also see Note 8,
<I>
	Financial Instruments
</I>
	, for information on the loss related to U.S. dollar interest rate swaps no longer designated as accounting cash flow
	hedges during the first quarters of 2016 and 2015.
</P>

</DIV>
</EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL">
	During 2016 and 2015, derivatives designated as accounting hedges include cash flow and fair value hedges and derivatives not
	designated as accounting hedges include economic hedges.
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Non-U.S.
</FONT>
	dollar denominated debt designated as a hedge of our net investments in
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-U.S.
</FONT>
	operations is not
	reflected in the table above, but is included in long-term debt summarized in Note 7,
<I>
	Debt and Borrowing Arrangements
</I>
	. We record derivative assets and liabilities on a gross basis in our consolidated balance sheet. The fair value of our asset
	derivatives is recorded within other current assets and the fair value of our liability derivatives is recorded within other current liabilities.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" ALIGN="CENTER">
	89
</P>

</DIV>
</EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL">
	Level&nbsp;1 financial assets and liabilities consist of exchange-traded commodity futures and listed options. The fair value of
	these instruments is determined based on quoted market prices on commodity exchanges. Our exchange-traded derivatives are generally subject to master netting arrangements that permit net settlement of transactions with the same counterparty when
	certain criteria are met, such as in the event of default. We also are required to maintain cash margin accounts in connection with funding the settlement of our open positions, and the margin requirements generally fluctuate daily based on market
	conditions. We have recorded margin deposits related to our exchange-traded derivatives of $133&nbsp;million as of December&nbsp;31, 2016 and margin deposits of $22&nbsp;million as of December&nbsp;31, 2015 within other current assets. Based on our
	net asset or liability positions with individual counterparties, in the event of default and immediate net settlement of all of our open positions, for derivatives we have in a net asset position, our counterparties would owe us a total of
	$48&nbsp;million as of December&nbsp;31, 2016 and $52&nbsp;million as of December&nbsp;31, 2015. For derivatives we have in a net liability position, we would owe $2&nbsp;million as of December&nbsp;31, 2016. As of December&nbsp;31, 2015, there were
	no Level&nbsp;1 derivatives in a net liability position.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL">
	Level&nbsp;2 financial assets and liabilities consist primarily of
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	over-the-counter
</FONT>
</FONT>
	(&#147;OTC&#148;) currency exchange forwards, options and swaps; commodity forwards and options; and interest rate swaps. Our currency exchange contracts are valued using an income approach
	based on observable market forward rates less the contract rate multiplied by the notional amount. Commodity derivatives are valued using an income approach based on the observable market commodity index prices less the contract rate multiplied by
	the notional amount or based on pricing models that rely on market observable inputs such as commodity prices. Our calculation of the fair value of interest rate swaps is derived from a discounted cash flow analysis based on the terms of the
	contract and the observable market interest rate curve. Our calculation of the fair value of financial instruments takes into consideration the risk of nonperformance, including counterparty credit risk. Our OTC derivative transactions are governed
	by International Swap Dealers Association agreements and other standard industry contracts. Under these agreements, we do not post nor require collateral from our counterparties. The majority of our commodity and currency exchange OTC derivatives do
	not have a legal right of
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	set-off.
</FONT>
	In connection with our OTC derivatives that could be
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	net-settled
</FONT>
	in the event of default, assuming all parties were to fail to comply
	with the terms of the agreements, for derivatives we have in a net liability position, we would owe $40&nbsp;million as of December&nbsp;31, 2016 and $101&nbsp;million as of December&nbsp;31, 2015, and for derivatives we have in a net asset
	position, our counterparties would owe us a total of $162&nbsp;million as of December&nbsp;31, 2016 and $64&nbsp;million as of December&nbsp;31, 2015. We manage the credit risk in connection with these and all our derivatives by entering into
	transactions with counterparties with investment grade credit ratings, limiting the amount of exposure with each counterparty and monitoring the financial condition of our counterparties.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" ALIGN="CENTER">
	90
</P>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL">
	Within interest and other expense, net, we recorded
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	pre-tax
</FONT>
	losses of $97&nbsp;million in
	the first quarter of 2016 and $34&nbsp;million in the first quarter of 2015 related to amounts excluded from effectiveness testing. These amounts relate to interest rate swaps no longer designated as cash flow hedges due to changes in financing
	plans. Due to lower overall costs and our decision to hedge a greater portion of our net investments in operations that use currencies other than the U.S. dollar as their functional currencies, we changed our plans to issue U.S. dollar-denominated
	debt and instead issued euro and Swiss franc-denominated notes in the current year first quarter, and euro, British pound sterling and Swiss franc-denominated notes in the prior-year first quarter. Amounts excluded from effectiveness testing were
	not material for the remainder of 2016 and 2015 and prior year periods.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" ALIGN="CENTER">
	91
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage94"></A>

	We record
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	pre-tax
</FONT>
	and
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	after-tax
</FONT>
	(i)&nbsp;gains or losses reclassified from accumulated other comprehensive earnings / (losses) into earnings, (ii)&nbsp;gains or losses on ineffectiveness and (iii)&nbsp;gains or losses on amounts excluded from effectiveness testing in:
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL">
	Based on current market conditions, we would expect to transfer losses of $31&nbsp;million (net of taxes) for commodity cash flow hedges, unrealized gains of
	$10&nbsp;million (net of taxes) for currency cash flow hedges and unrealized losses of $2&nbsp;million (net of taxes) for interest rate cash flow hedges to earnings during the next 12 months.
</P>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL">
	In connection with the coffee business transactions, we entered into a number of consecutive euro to U.S. dollar currency exchange
	forward contracts in 2015 and 2014 to lock in an equivalent expected value in U.S. dollars. The
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	mark-to-market
</FONT>
</FONT>
	gains and losses on the derivatives were recorded in
	earnings. We recorded net gains of $436&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015 and $628&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014 within interest and other expense, net in connection with the forward contracts and the
	transferring of proceeds to our subsidiaries where coffee net assets and shares were deconsolidated. The currency hedge and related gains and losses were recorded within interest and other expense, net. See Note 2,
<I>
	Divestitures and Acquisitions
	&#151; JDE Coffee Business Transactions
</I>
	, for additional information.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" ALIGN="CENTER">
	92
</P>

</EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL">
<B>
	Note 9. Benefit Plans
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL">
<B>
	Pension
	Plans
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL">
	Prior to the July&nbsp;2, 2015 closing of the coffee business transactions, certain active employees who transitioned to JDE participated in our
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Non-U.S.
</FONT>
	pension plans. Following the transactions, benefits began to be provided directly by JDE to participants continuing with JDE. JDE assumed certain pension plan obligations and received the related plan
	assets. In 2015, we reduced our net benefit plan liabilities by $131&nbsp;million and the related deferred tax assets by $24&nbsp;million. For participants that elected not to transfer into the JDE plans, we retained the plan obligations and related
	plan assets.
</P>
<EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<A NAME="FIS_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE_63"></A>

<A NAME="eolPage96"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D288385D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL">
	The accumulated benefit obligation, which represents benefits earned to the measurement date, was $1,540&nbsp;million at
	December&nbsp;31, 2016 and $1,463&nbsp;million at December&nbsp;31, 2015 for the U.S. pension plans. The accumulated benefit obligation for the
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-U.S.
</FONT>
	pension plans was $9,531&nbsp;million at
	December&nbsp;31, 2016 and $9,267&nbsp;million at December&nbsp;31,&nbsp;2015.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL">
	For salaried and
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-union
</FONT>
	hourly employees
	hired after January&nbsp;1, 2009, we discontinued benefits under our U.S. pension plans and replaced them with an enhanced Company contribution to our employee defined contribution plan. Effective December&nbsp;31, 2019, benefit accruals will cease
	under the U.S.
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-union
</FONT>
	pension plan. For
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-union
</FONT>
	employees participating in that plan on December&nbsp;31, 2019, we will calculate the pension benefit obligation
	based on pay and service as of that date and no longer accrue new benefits.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL">
	The combined U.S. and
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-U.S.
</FONT>
	pension plans
	resulted in a net pension liability of $1,882&nbsp;million at December&nbsp;31, 2016 and $2,145&nbsp;million at December&nbsp;31, 2015. We recognized these amounts in our consolidated balance sheets as follows:
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:12PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL">
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Year-end
</FONT>
	discount rates for our U.S., Canadian, Eurozone and U.K. plans were developed
	from a model portfolio of high quality,
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	fixed-income
</FONT>
	debt instruments with durations that match the expected future cash flows of the benefit obligations.
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Year-end
</FONT>
	discount rates for our remaining
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-U.S.
</FONT>
	plans were developed from local bond indices that match local benefit obligations as closely as possible. Changes in our discount rates were primarily the result of
	changes in bond yields
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	year-over-year.
</FONT>
</FONT>
	We determine our expected rate of return on plan assets from the plan assets&#146; historical long-term investment performance,
	current asset allocation and estimates of future long-term returns by asset class.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL">
	At the end of 2015, we changed the approach used to measure service and interest
	costs for pension benefits. For 2015, we measured service and interest costs utilizing a single weighted-average discount rate derived from the yield curve used to measure the plan obligations. For 2016, we measured service and interest costs by
	applying the specific spot rates along that yield curve to the plans&#146; liability cash flows. We believe the new approach provided a more precise measurement of service and interest costs by aligning the timing of the plans&#146; liability cash
	flows to the corresponding spot rates on the yield curve. The impact of this change was a decrease in net periodic pension cost of approximately $64&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2016. This change did not affect the measurement
	of our plan obligations. We accounted for this change as a change in accounting estimate and, accordingly, accounted for it on a prospective basis.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" ALIGN="CENTER">
	94
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage97"></A>

</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	For the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015, amortization of prior service cost includes $17&nbsp;million of pension curtailment losses related to employees who transitioned to JDE upon the contribution of our global
	coffee business. Refer to Note 2
<I>
	, Divestitures and Acquisitions &#150; JDE Coffee Business Transactions
</I>
	, for more information.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL; FONT-SIZE:8PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="2%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	(2)
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	Settlement losses include $15&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2016 and $9&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015 of pension settlement losses for employees who elected
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	lump-sum
</FONT>
	payments in connection with our 2014-2018 Restructuring Program. Retired employees who elected
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	lump-sum
</FONT>
	payments resulted in net settlement losses in 2016 of
	$15&nbsp;million for our U.S. plans and $6&nbsp;million for our
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-U.S.
</FONT>
	plans and in 2015 of $10&nbsp;million for our U.S. plans and $2&nbsp;million for our
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-U.S.
</FONT>
	plans. Employees who elected
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	lump-sum
</FONT>
	payments in connection with our 2012-2014 Restructuring Program and cost saving initiatives and retired employees who elected
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	lump-sum
</FONT>
	payments resulted in net settlement losses for our U.S. plans of $28&nbsp;million in 2014. In addition, we incurred special termination benefit costs of $2&nbsp;million in 2014 in the
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-U.S.
</FONT>
	plans related to the 2012-2014 Restructuring Program. See Note 6,
<I>
	Restructuring Programs
</I>
	, for more information. We recorded an additional $90&nbsp;million of pension settlement losses related to the
	coffee business transactions within the gain on the coffee business transactions. Refer to Note 2
<I>
	, Divestitures and Acquisitions &#150; JDE Coffee Business Transactions
</I>
	, for more information.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL">
	For the U.S. plans, we determine the expected return on plan assets component of net periodic benefit cost using a calculated market return value that recognizes the
	cost over a four year period. For our
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-U.S.
</FONT>
	plans, we utilize a similar approach with varying cost recognition periods for some plans, and with others, we determine the expected return on plan assets based
	on asset fair values as of the measurement date.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL">
	As of December&nbsp;31, 2016, for the combined U.S. and
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-U.S.
</FONT>
	pension
	plans, we expected to amortize from accumulated other comprehensive earnings / (losses) into net periodic pension cost during 2017:
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="5%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	&#149;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	an estimated $202&nbsp;million of net loss from experience differences; and
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="5%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	&#149;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	$1&nbsp;million of estimated prior service credit.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>

	We used the following
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	weighted-average
</FONT>
	assumptions to determine our net periodic pension cost:
</P>

	96
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage99"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D288385D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL">
	We excluded plan assets of $62&nbsp;million at December&nbsp;31, 2016 and $66&nbsp;million at December&nbsp;31, 2015 from
	the above tables related to certain insurance contracts as they are reported at contract value, in accordance with authoritative guidance.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL">
<I>
	Fair value
	measurements:
</I>
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="5%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	&#149;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	Level&nbsp;1 &#150; includes primarily U.S and
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-U.S.
</FONT>
	equity securities and government bonds valued using quoted prices in active markets.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="5%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	&#149;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	Level&nbsp;2 &#150; includes primarily pooled funds, including assets in real estate pooled funds, valued using net asset values of participation units held in common collective trusts, as reported by the managers of
	the trusts and as supported by the unit prices of actual purchase and sale transactions. Level&nbsp;2 plan assets also include corporate bonds and other fixed-income securities, valued using independent observable market inputs, such as matrix
	pricing, yield curves and indices.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="5%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	&#149;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	Level&nbsp;3 &#150; includes investments valued using unobservable inputs that reflect the plans&#146; assumptions that market participants would use in pricing the assets, based on the best information available.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="9%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	&#149;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	Fair value estimates for pooled funds are calculated by the investment advisor when reliable quotations or pricing services are not readily available for certain underlying securities. The estimated value is based on
	either cost or last sale price for most of the securities valued in this fashion.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="9%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	&#149;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	Fair value estimates for private equity investments are calculated by the general partners using the market approach to estimate the fair value of private investments. The market approach utilizes prices and other
	relevant information generated by market transactions, type of security, degree of liquidity, restrictions on the disposition, latest round of financing data, company financial statements, relevant valuation multiples and discounted cash flow
	analyses.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="9%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	&#149;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	Fair value estimates for real estate investments are calculated by the investment managers using the present value of future cash flows expected to be received from the investments, based on valuation methodologies such
	as appraisals, local market conditions, and current and projected operating performance.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="9%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	&#149;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	Fair value estimates for investments in hedge
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	fund-of-funds
</FONT>
</FONT>
	are calculated by the investment managers using the net asset value per share
	of the investment as reported by the money managers of the underlying funds.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="9%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	&#149;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	Fair value estimates for certain fixed-income securities such as insurance contracts are calculated based on the future stream of benefit payments discounted using prevailing interest rates based on the valuation date.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="5%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	&#149;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	Net asset value &#150; primarily includes real estate funds, hedge funds and private equity investments for which net asset values are normally used.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL">
	Changes in our Level&nbsp;3 plan assets, which are recorded in other comprehensive earnings / (losses), included:
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:12PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>

<A NAME="eolPage100"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D288385D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL">
	The decreases in Level&nbsp;3 pension plan investments during 2016 were primarily due to net settlements in real estate
	funds and the effects of currency. The decreases in Level&nbsp;3 pension plan investments during 2015 were primarily due to net settlements in hedge funds and the effects of currency.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL">
	The percentage of fair value of pension plan assets was:
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:12PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;

</DIV>
</EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL">
	For our U.S. plans, our investment strategy is to reduce the risk of underfunded plans in part through appropriate asset
	allocation within our plan assets. We attempt to maintain our target asset allocation by rebalancing between asset classes as we make contributions and monthly benefit payments. The strategy involves using indexed U.S. equity and international
	equity securities and actively managed U.S. investment grade fixed-income securities (which constitute 95% or more of fixed-income securities) with smaller allocations to high yield fixed-income securities.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL">
	For our
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-U.S.
</FONT>
	plans, the investment strategy is subject to local regulations and the asset / liability profiles of the plans
	in each individual country. In aggregate, the asset allocation targets of our
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-U.S.
</FONT>
	plans are broadly characterized as a mix of approximately 34% equity securities (including investments in real estate),
	approximately 64% fixed-income securities and approximately 2% other alternative securities. Our investment strategy for our largest
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-U.S.
</FONT>
	plan, which comprises 63% of our
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-U.S.
</FONT>
	pension assets, is designed to balance risk and return by diversifying across a wide range of return-seeking and liability matching assets, invested in a range of both active and passive mandates. We
	target an allocation of approximately 24% in equity securities, 21% credit, 6% private markets, 9% other diversifying assets, and 40% liability matching assets. The strategy uses indexed global developed equities, actively managed global investment
	grade and alternative credit, global private equity and real estate, other diversifying assets including hedge funds, and other liability matching assets including a
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	buy-in
</FONT>
	annuity policy.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL">
<I>
	Employer Contributions:
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL">
	In 2016, we contributed $378&nbsp;million (of which,
	$350&nbsp;million was voluntarily contributed) to our U.S. pension plans and $403&nbsp;million (of which, $100&nbsp;million was a
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-recurring
</FONT>
	contribution related to merging our legacy Cadbury plans in the
	United Kingdom) to our
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-U.S.
</FONT>
	pension plans. In addition, employees contributed $16&nbsp;million to our
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-U.S.
</FONT>
	plans. We make contributions to our U.S. and
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-U.S.
</FONT>
	pension plans primarily to the extent that they are tax deductible and do not generate an excise tax liability.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL">
	In 2017,
	we estimate that our pension contributions will be $13&nbsp;million to our U.S. plans and $455&nbsp;million to our
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-U.S.
</FONT>
	plans based on current tax laws. Of the total 2017 pension contributions,
	$250&nbsp;million is expected to be non-recurring. Our actual contributions may be different due to many factors, including changes in tax and other benefit laws, significant differences between expected and actual pension asset performance or
	interest rates.
</P>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL">
<I>
	Multiemployer Pension Plans:
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL">
	In
	accordance with obligations we have under collective bargaining agreements, we made contributions to multiemployer pension plans of $25&nbsp;million in 2016, $31&nbsp;million in 2015 and $32&nbsp;million in 2014. There are risks of participating in
	multiemployer pension plans that are different from single employer plans. Assets contributed to a multiemployer plan by one employer may be used to provide benefits to employees of other participating employers. If a participating employer stops
	contributing to the plan, the unfunded obligations of the plan are borne by the remaining participating employers. If the Company stops participating in its multi-employer pension plans, the Company may be required to pay those plans an amount based
	on its allocable share of the unfunded vested benefits of the plans, referred to as a withdrawal liability.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" ALIGN="CENTER">
	98
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage101"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D288385D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL">
	The only individually significant multiemployer plan we participate in as of December&nbsp;31, 2016 is the Bakery and
	Confectionery Union and Industry International Pension Fund (the &#147;Fund&#148;). Our contributions to the Fund exceeded 5% of total contributions to the Fund for fiscal years 2016, 2015 and 2014. Our contributions to the Fund were
	$21&nbsp;million in 2016, $27&nbsp;million in 2015 and $25&nbsp;million in 2014. Our contributions to other multiemployer pension plans that were not individually significant were $4&nbsp;million in 2016, $4&nbsp;million in 2015 and $7&nbsp;million
	in 2014. Our contributions are based on our contribution rates under our collective bargaining agreements, the number of our eligible employees and Fund surcharges.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:12PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL">
	Effective January&nbsp;1, 2012, the Fund&#146;s zone status changed to &#147;Red&#148;. As a result of this certification,
	beginning in July 2012, we were charged a 10% surcharge on our contribution rates. The Fund subsequently adopted a rehabilitation plan on November&nbsp;7, 2012 that required contribution increases and reductions to benefit provisions. Although our
	collective bargaining agreements with the Fund expired during 2016, we are obligated to make contributions to the Fund and we continue to work with the union toward reaching an agreement. The Fund&#146;s actuarial valuation was last completed as of
	January&nbsp;1, 2016. As of August&nbsp;28, 2016, the 10% surcharge is no longer applicable but we are required to pay higher contributions under the Fund&#146;s rehabilitation plan.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL">
<I>
	Other Costs:
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL">
	We sponsor and contribute to employee defined contribution
	plans. These plans cover eligible salaried,
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-union
</FONT>
	and union employees. Our contributions and costs are determined by the matching of employee contributions, as defined by the plans. Amounts charged to
	expense in continuing operations for defined contribution plans totaled $44&nbsp;million in 2016, $45&nbsp;million in 2015 and $46&nbsp;million in 2014.
</P>
<EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL">
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Year-end
</FONT>
	discount rates for our U.S., Canadian and U.K. plans were developed from a model
	portfolio of high quality,
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	fixed-income
</FONT>
	debt instruments with durations that match the expected future cash flows of the benefit obligations.
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Year-end
</FONT>
	discount rates for
	our remaining
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-U.S.
</FONT>
	plans were developed from local bond indices that match local benefit obligations as closely as possible. Changes in our discount rates were primarily the result of changes in bond
	yields year-over-year. Our expected health care cost trend rate is based on historical costs.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL">
	At the end 2015, we changed the approach used to measure service and
	interest costs for other postretirement benefits. For 2015, we measured service and interest costs utilizing a single weighted-average discount rate derived from the yield curve used to measure the plan obligations. For 2016, we measured service and
	interest costs by applying the specific spot rates along that yield curve to the plans&#146; liability cash flows. We believe the new approach provided a more precise measurement of service and interest costs by aligning the timing of the
	plans&#146; liability cash flows to the corresponding spot rates on the yield curve. The impact of this change was a decrease in net periodic postretirement cost of approximately $4&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2016. This change
	does not affect the measurement of our plan obligations. We accounted for this change as a change in accounting estimate and, accordingly, accounted for it on a prospective basis.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL">
	Assumed health care cost trend rates have a significant impact on the amounts reported for the health care plans. A
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	one-percentage-point
</FONT>
</FONT>
	change in assumed health care cost trend rates would have the following effects:
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:12PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<A NAME="FIS_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE_77"></A>
<DIV ALIGN="RIGHT">

	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	(1)
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	For the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2016, amortization of prior service credit includes $9&nbsp;million of curtailment gain related to a change in the eligibility requirement.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL">
	As of December&nbsp;31, 2016, we expected to amortize from accumulated other comprehensive earnings / (losses) into
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	pre-tax
</FONT>
	net
	periodic postretirement health care costs during 2017:
</P>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL">
<I>
	Other Costs:
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL">
	We made contributions to
	multiemployer medical plans totaling $19&nbsp;million in 2016, $20&nbsp;million in 2015 and $18&nbsp;million in 2014. These plans provide medical benefits to active employees and retirees under certain collective bargaining agreements.
</P>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL">
	The accrued benefit obligation was determined using a weighted-average discount rate of 6.2% in 2016 and 2015, an assumed
	weighted-average ultimate annual turnover rate of 0.3% in 2016 and 2015, assumed compensation cost increases of 4.0% in 2016 and 2015 and assumed benefits as defined in the respective plans.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL">
	Postemployment costs arising from actions that offer employees benefits in excess of those specified in the respective plans are charged to expense when incurred.
</P>

	As of December&nbsp;31, 2016, the estimated net gain for the postemployment benefit plans that we expected to amortize from
	accumulated other comprehensive earnings / (losses) into net periodic postemployment costs during 2017 was approximately $4&nbsp;million.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">

	101
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage104"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D288385D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL">
<B>
	Note 10. Stock Plans
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL">
	Under our
	Amended and Restated 2005 Performance Incentive Plan (the &#147;Plan&#148;), we are authorized through May&nbsp;21, 2024 to issue a maximum of 243.7&nbsp;million shares of our Common Stock to employees and
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-employee
</FONT>
	directors. As of December&nbsp;31, 2016, there were 74.2&nbsp;million shares available to be granted under the Plan.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL">
<I>
	Stock Options:
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL">
	Stock options (including stock appreciation rights) are
	granted at an exercise price equal to the market value of the underlying stock on the grant date, generally become exercisable in three annual installments beginning on the first anniversary of the grant date and have a maximum term of ten years.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL">
	We account for our employee stock options under the fair value method of accounting using a
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Black-Scholes
</FONT>
	methodology to
	measure stock option expense at the date of grant. The fair value of the stock options at the date of grant is amortized to expense over the vesting period. We recorded compensation expense related to stock options held by our employees of
	$57&nbsp;million in 2016, $50&nbsp;million in 2015 and $47&nbsp;million in 2014 in our results from continuing operations. The deferred tax benefit recorded related to this compensation expense was $15&nbsp;million in 2016, $13&nbsp;million in 2015
	and $12&nbsp;million in 2014. The unamortized compensation expense related to our employee stock options was $52&nbsp;million at December&nbsp;31, 2016 and is expected to be recognized over a weighted-average period of 1&nbsp;year.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL">
	Our weighted-average Black-Scholes fair value assumptions were:
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:12PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<A NAME="FIS_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE_83"></A>
<DIV ALIGN="RIGHT">
<TABLE CELLSPACING="0" CELLPADDING="0" WIDTH="93.4%" BORDER="0" STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL; FONT-SIZE:10PT">
<TR STYLE="VISIBILITY:HIDDEN; LINE-HEIGHT:0PT; COLOR:WHITE">
<TD WIDTH="45%">
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM" WIDTH="6%">
</TD>
<TD>
</TD>
<TD NOWRAP STYLE="ARIAL; ">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM" WIDTH="6%">
</TD>
<TD>
</TD>
<TD NOWRAP STYLE="ARIAL; ">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
</TD>

</TD>
<TD>
</TD>

	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
</TD>

</TD>
<TD>
</TD>

	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;

	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
</TD>
</TR>
<TR STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM" COLSPAN="2" ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="BORDER-BOTTOM:1.00PX SOLID #000000">
<B>
	Risk-Free
<BR>
	Interest&nbsp;Rate
</B>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL">
	The risk-free interest rate represents the constant maturity U.S. government treasuries rate with a remaining term equal to the
	expected life of the options. The expected life is the period over which our employees are expected to hold their options. Volatility reflects historical movements in our stock price for a period commensurate with the expected life of the options.
	The dividend yield reflects the dividend yield in place at the time of the historical grants.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">

	102

	(1)
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	Cash received from options exercised was $221&nbsp;million in 2016, $148&nbsp;million in 2015 and $168&nbsp;million in 2014. The actual tax benefit realized for the tax deductions from the option exercises totaled
	$31&nbsp;million in 2016, $58&nbsp;million in 2015 and $29&nbsp;million in 2014.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL; FONT-SIZE:8PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
